story.title: Hot for a Hero - Episode 1
story.storyDescription: Trista: Hey! This is Trista, the klutzy hiker from last weekend‚Ä¶
story.creator: web-uploader

author.bio: Chris Marie Green writes hot contemporary romance (like ‚ÄúBedroomies‚Äù!) plus urban fantasy. She also loves devouring pop culture and avoiding international incidents while traveling.

messages.text: Hey! This is Trista, the klutzy hiker from last weekend‚Ä¶
You know, the girl who fell off the trail and needed you to rescue her‚Ä¶
üòä
Hey, Trista. How could I forget?
It‚Äôs not everyday I get to put my superpowers to such good use üí™
I hope you don‚Äôt mind that I asked around for your number.
I wanted to thank you again for fearlessly climbing down that embankment to help me.
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è It was nothing.
That‚Äôs not true!
I was panicking because I thought I was going to be trapped down there.
My phone wasn‚Äôt getting reception‚Ä¶
And THEN I saw that snake winding its way over the rock below me.
Thank God you heard me yelling!
I just happened to be around to help out.
But you also stayed afterward to make sure I was okay.
And you even walked me down to my car üíñ
All in a day‚Äôs work!
Most guys would‚Äôve made me feel like an idiot for hiking alone.
Or laughed at me for tumbling off the trail while taking a picture of a chipmunk.
But you didn‚Äôt nag at me for being the ‚ÄúAirhead of the Campus.‚Äù
That‚Äôs because you‚Äôre clearly not an airhead ‚Äî just an avid chipmunk fan üêø
LOL
So did I end up ruining your geology grade? üò¨
I‚Äôve been worried that you didn‚Äôt collect enough rocks for your project, all because of me.
Hal starts to tell Trista that the rocks were for his own personal collection‚Ä¶
But thinks better of it. He deletes the words, sending a new text.
The rocks weren‚Äôt important.
üòÖ Thank goodness.
So what‚Äôre you up to tonight, SuperHal?
I‚Äôd love to take my hero out to dinner and a movie!
Hal almost spits coffee onto his phone.
His roommate Fred raises an eyebrow at him.
What was THAT about?
I think a girl just asked me on a date.
Hal pushes his phone across the dining hall table to Fred.
Fred scrolls through the texts.
This is a DEFINITE ask!!
But it doesn‚Äôt make sense.
Why??
Because freshman dweebs like us never get asked out by girls.
WE barely even have the guts to ask THEM out!
Frankly, I only approached this one because she fell off a hiking trail.
Fred rolls his eyes, but Hal gestures to himself as proof‚Ä¶
Lanky body, careless hair‚Ä¶
And he‚Äôs wearing a goofy robot dinosaur tee shirt for good measure.
In other words, he‚Äôs a gamer and a brain ‚Äî not exactly stud material.
Who cares about our deficient dating history when you‚Äôve got opportunity knocking?!
You‚Äôre not getting it‚Ä¶
This girl obviously remembers me as a hero.
The only time I can truly pass for that is when I‚Äôm playing one on an Xbox!
Also, she just happens to be Trista Harrison.
TRISTA HARRISON?
She‚Äôs in my biology lab.
And she‚Äôs constantly surrounded by the football team.
Exactly! I‚Äôm nothing compared to those Thors she usually dates.
But weren‚Äôt you enough of a Thor that day?
You pulled her back up to the hiking trail!
Yeah, but that‚Äôs only because I was pumped on adrenalin.
See! Every hero has an origin story!
Fred, you and I both know the only reason she‚Äôs acting like this.
Misattribution of arousal.
I heard the word AROUSAL, but you lost me on the rest.
It‚Äôs when people are in a heightened state of stress.
So they misinterpret their response to fear.
Fred‚Äôs eyes glaze over, so Hal slaps the table.
Fear produces adrenalin, right?
That makes a person feel the same way they do when they‚Äôre attracted to someone.
So think about it ‚Äî Trista was scared and in trouble when I came along.
THAT‚ÄôS why she was mislabeling the situation as something romantic.
It didn‚Äôt actually have anything to do with me.
Well, what were YOU feeling?
Hal searches for an answer.
You were into her!
Hal glares at him.
Come on, Prince Charming, just admit it was a romantic moment for you.
Hal throws up his hands.
How could it not be?
Trista kept looking at me in a way no one has ever looked at me before.
Just for a moment, I thought that‚Ä¶
You might have a chance with her in real life?
Yeah.
But forget that.
If she saw me again without all the adrenalin and fear running through her‚Ä¶
She would realize I‚Äôm just a rock-collecting, Xbox-playing dweeb.
Fred scratches his tousled hair.
Well, maybe there‚Äôs another way of looking at this‚Ä¶
Hal raises an eyebrow.
Could it be that she thought you were pretty cool?
Even after the adrenalin wore off?
Hal shakes his head.
Life just doesn‚Äôt work that way for guys like him and Fred.
Just then, Hal‚Äôs phone dings with a text.
His heart jumps with hope.
But what good is hope?
It would be smarter to end Trista‚Äôs misconceptions now.
Dinner will be a huge disaster.
Especially when Trista realizes just how misattributed her arousal really WAS.
Are you there?
Yeah. Listen, it‚Äôs great that you want to thank me with dinner and a movie‚Ä¶
But you don‚Äôt have to go out of your way like that.
Just stay away from chipmunks from now on, and that‚Äôll be thanks enough üòÄ
Trista doesn‚Äôt answer.
Even Fred is quiet.
Hal‚Äôs stomach clenches.
But he knows he made the right decision.
It‚Äôs better than meeting Trista again.
He can‚Äôt bear to see the disappointment in her eyes.
He‚Äôs no hero at all.
2 hours later
Hal enters his dorm.
He stops short when he arrives at his floor‚Äôs nearly empty common area.
Trista, with her big blue eyes and long blond hair, has been waiting for him.
Hal‚Äôs blood races hot and fast, just as it did on the mountain.
Before he can stop himself, he smiles.
Then he comes to his senses.
He clears his throat as she gets up from her chair.
I didn‚Äôt know you lived here.
I don‚Äôt.
But I found out that you do.
Can we talk?
Hal takes a breath. Here it goes‚Ä¶
Trista‚Äôs about to realize there was never any attraction between them.
But then, what he sees in Trista‚Äôs gaze stuns him‚Äî
There‚Äôs a soft longing in it‚Ä¶
And it echoes what Hal‚Äôs been feeling since the moment he met her.
I believe in being direct, so I‚Äôm just going to ask you straight out‚Ä¶
Are you blowing me off because of my ditzy reputation?
Hal blinks.
I know everyone thinks I‚Äôm just a party girl who runs around with the jocks.
And clearly, I also do brilliant things like fall off hiking trails‚Ä¶
And I know you‚Äôre a smart guy.
You must think I‚Äôm a dope, even though you were too polite to say so.
Trista‚Ä¶
But I want you to know that I‚Äôm more than all that.
Sure, it‚Äôs true that I‚Äôve been going a little crazy here at college‚Äî
I like that football players pay attention to a silly freshman like me‚Ä¶
And yeah, I‚Äôve been going to a few too many parties.
But I was hoping you saw the real me when we were up on the mountain.
A few minutes tick by as Hal absorbs every word.
This is too good to be true.
Surely, Trista‚Äôs going to change her mind at any moment‚Ä¶
Okay. I guess I just made a fool out of myself yet again.
She starts to walk off.
But then Hal does something that surprises even him‚Äî
He reaches out and grasps her hand.
The shock between them is like lightening.
And both of them freeze.
Then, emboldened, Hal entwines his fingers with hers‚Ä¶
Just as he did before he pulled her to safety on the mountain.
I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre shallow at all, Trista.
It‚Äôs just that guys like me don‚Äôt really get their hopes up when it comes to girls.
In case you haven‚Äôt noticed, I‚Äôm not exactly a smooth operator.
Hal shifts nervously.
It‚Äôs even possible that, on the mountain, you were feeling something called misattribution of arousal.
It‚Äôs when‚Äî
A person is frightened and the adrenalin makes her feel as if she‚Äôs attracted to whoever she‚Äôs with during a dangerous situation?
Hal feels his jaw drop.
Trista tilts her head and smiles.
I might have an airhead reputation‚Ä¶
But I do pay attention in general psychology class, Hal.
As warmth consumes Hal, he gathers enough courage to pull Trista a little closer.
Wait, I think I just figured out why you rejected me.
Did you think that, if we went out‚Ä¶
I would suddenly realize that I wasn‚Äôt ever attracted to you or something?
Yeah. That‚Äôs actually exactly what worried me.
Her grip tightens in his, and his heart pounds.
But I like you for so many reasons!
You were kind and attentive to me that day.
And no one has ever shown me such care or concern.
You really were my hero, Hal.
And it wasn‚Äôt just because of your show of strength.
Hal sees a light in Trista‚Äôs eyes and throws caution to the wind.
He slips his other hand into hers.
I‚Äôm really sorry I hung my issues up on you.
That wasn‚Äôt fair of me.
And I didn‚Äôt mean to make you feel shallow or anything less than you are.
Well, you‚Äôre making me feel pretty great right now.
As she runs her thumbs over his‚Ä¶
A heat flashes through him.
So‚Ä¶how about that dinner tonight?
Maybe we could go for another walk afterward.
He holds his breath, waiting, hoping‚Ä¶
As long as that walk doesn‚Äôt include chipmunks, it sounds perfect.
Hal loses himself in her smile.
They start walking, still holding hands‚Ä¶
Connecting in a way that‚Äôs impossible to misattribute.
